wiki_catalogs.name: Project Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the Mem0 project. Explain its purpose as an intelligent memory layer for AI agents, enabling personalized and persistent memory across interactions. Detail the core value proposition: transforming stateless LLMs into context-aware assistants through user, session, and agent-level memory. Document the architecture at a high level, highlighting the integration between LLMs, vector databases, graph databases, and history tracking. Include real-world use cases such as customer support chatbots, healthcare assistants, and productivity tools. Provide conceptual overviews for beginners while including technical depth on memory inference, procedural memory, and multi-modal storage. Use terminology consistent with the codebase like 'memory inference', 'vector stores', and 'graph memory'. Include practical examples from the README and LLM.md to illustrate key capabilities. Address common misconceptions and clarify how Mem0 differs from standard RAG systems.

wiki_catalogs.name: Memory Types
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the three-tiered memory system: User, Session, and Agent state. Explain how User memory stores long-term personal facts, Session memory tracks short-term conversation context, and Agent state manages task-specific procedural knowledge. Use examples from main.py to demonstrate instantiation and interaction between memory types. Detail how configuration parameters in base.py affect memory behavior and isolation. Illustrate with code snippets showing memory creation with different scopes and their impact on personalization. Address common use cases for each type and integration patterns in AI applications. Include guidance on choosing the appropriate memory type for specific scenarios and troubleshooting scope-related issues.

wiki_catalogs.name: Vector Store Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for Vector Store Configuration. Explain the role of vector databases in memory retrieval and similarity search. Document configuration parameters for each supported vector store including Chroma, Qdrant, Pinecone, Weaviate, FAISS, OpenSearch, and others. Provide code examples showing initialization and provider-specific settings such as API keys, host URLs, and collection names. Highlight differences in performance, scalability, and deployment models (cloud vs. self-hosted). Include best practices for choosing the right vector store based on use case requirements. Address common issues like connection failures, authentication errors, and schema mismatches. Explain how the VectorStoreFactory uses these configurations to instantiate providers dynamically.

wiki_catalogs.name: Adding Memories
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for adding memories. Thoroughly explain the `add()` method implementation, including its parameters (messages, user_id, agent_id, run_id, metadata, infer, memory_type, prompt), return values, and invocation relationships. Document the difference between inferred fact extraction (when infer=True) and direct raw memory addition (when infer=False). Explain procedural memory creation using memory_type='procedural_memory'. Include concrete examples from main.py showing synchronous usage patterns for chatbot memory management and user preference tracking. Detail the internal workflow involving fact extraction via LLM, vector embedding generation, and concurrent storage in vector and graph databases. Address common issues like message format validation errors and provide solutions. Include performance considerations for batch operations and large message lists.

wiki_catalogs.name: Design Patterns
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the design patterns used in the Mem0 system. Detail the Factory Pattern implementation in `factory.py` for creating LLM, embedder, vector store, and graph store instances. Explain how Dependency Injection is used through configuration objects to decouple components. Document the Abstract Base Classes (ABCs) like `MemoryBase` and `Base` classes across modules that define interfaces for extensibility. Describe how the Plugin Architecture enables seamless integration of new providers without modifying core logic. Include code examples showing provider registration and resolution. Address best practices for extending these patterns and common pitfalls to avoid when implementing custom providers.

wiki_catalogs.name: Supported Providers
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for all supported providers in the Mem0 ecosystem. Detail each provider for vector databases (Qdrant, Chroma, Pinecone, Weaviate, FAISS, etc.), LLMs (OpenAI, Anthropic, Azure, Gemini, Ollama, etc.), embedding models (OpenAI, HuggingFace, VertexAI, etc.), and graph stores (Memgraph, Neptune, Kuzu, etc.). For each provider, document configuration requirements, authentication methods, connection parameters, and status (stable, experimental, deprecated). Include code examples showing how to configure each provider in both Python and environment variables. Explain integration patterns and performance characteristics. Address common setup issues and troubleshooting steps for each provider. Link to official provider documentation where applicable.

wiki_catalogs.name: Memory Class
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive API documentation for the Memory class, the primary interface for memory operations in the mem0 framework. Document all public methods including add(), get(), get_all(), search(), update(), delete(), and delete_all(), detailing their parameters, return types, exceptions, and usage patterns. Explain the initialization process via __init__() and from_config(), including configuration injection and factory-based component creation (LLM, embedder, vector store). Describe the role of the MemoryBase abstract class and inheritance pattern. Provide practical examples for each method, showing both simple and complex usage scenarios. Document the API versioning system (v1.0 vs v1.1) and deprecation warnings. Include error handling strategies and common troubleshooting tips for failed operations. Address performance considerations for concurrent operations and thread safety.

wiki_overview.content:
<blog>
# Comprehensive Project Analysis: Mem0 - The Memory Layer for Personalized AI

## 1. Project Introduction

### Purpose Statement
Mem0 is an intelligent memory layer designed to enhance AI assistants and agents with personalized, long-term memory capabilities. It enables AI systems to remember user preferences, adapt to individual needs, and continuously learn over time, creating more natural and context-rich interactions.

### Core Goals and Objectives
- Provide a scalable memory solution for AI agents that improves accuracy by 26% over standard approaches
- Reduce response latency by 91% through efficient memory retrieval
- Decrease token usage by 90% compared to full-context approaches
- Support multi-level memory (User, Session, and Agent state) with adaptive personalization
- Offer both hosted platform and self-hosted open-source options

### Target Audience
- AI developers building personalized assistants and chatbots
- Enterprises implementing customer support systems
- Healthcare providers requiring patient history tracking
- Productivity tool developers creating adaptive workflows
- Gaming companies developing responsive AI characters

## 2. Technical Architecture

### Component Breakdown
The Mem0 architecture consists of several core components that work together to provide intelligent memory management:

- **Memory Core**: Central component handling memory operations (add, search, update, delete)
- **Vector Stores**: Multiple vector database integrations for semantic memory storage
- **Graph Stores**: Graph database support for relationship-based memory
- **LLM Integration**: Support for various language models as reasoning engines
- **Embedding Models**: Multiple embedding providers for text vectorization
- **Configuration System**: Flexible configuration through YAML and Python classes

### Design Patterns
The project employs several key design patterns:

- **Factory Pattern**: Used extensively through factory classes for LLMs, embedders, vector stores, and graph stores
- **Dependency Injection**: Configuration objects are injected into components
- **Abstract Base Classes**: MemoryBase defines the interface for memory operations
- **Async/Sync Parallel Implementation**: Both synchronous and asynchronous versions of core functionality
- **Plugin Architecture**: Extensible design allowing new providers to be registered

### System Relationships
```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[Client Application] --> B[Memory Interface]
    B --> C[LLM Provider]
    B --> D[Embedding Model]
    B --> E[Vector Store]
    B --> F[Graph Store]
    B --> G[SQLite History]
    C --> H[External LLM API]
    D --> I[External Embedding API]
    E --> J[External Vector DB]
    F --> K[External Graph DB]
    style B fill:#f9f,stroke:#333
```

### Data Flow Diagram
```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[User Input] --> B[Memory.add()]
    B --> C{Infer?}
    C -->|Yes| D[LLM Fact Extraction]
    C -->|No| E[Direct Storage]
    D --> F[Vector Search for Similar Memories]
    F --> G[LLM Memory Update Decision]
    G --> H[Apply ADD/UPDATE/DELETE]
    H --> I[Vector Store]
    H --> J[Graph Store]
    H --> K[SQLite History]
    I --> L[Memory.search()]
    J --> L
    K --> L
    L --> M[Relevant Memories]
    M --> N[LLM Response Generation]
    N --> O[Final Response]
```

## 3. Key Implementation

### Main Entry Points
- `mem0.memory.main.Memory` - Primary synchronous memory interface
- `mem0.memory.main.AsyncMemory` - Asynchronous memory interface
- `mem0.client.main.MemoryClient` - Client interface for external applications

### Core Modules
- **Memory Management**: `mem0/memory/main.py` - Core memory operations
- **Configuration**: `mem0/configs/` - Configuration classes and enums
- **Factories**: `mem0/utils/factory.py` - Provider creation and management
- **Storage**: `mem0/memory/storage.py` - SQLite history management
- **Telemetry**: `mem0/memory/telemetry.py` - Usage analytics

### Configuration Approach
The system uses a hierarchical configuration approach with default values and environment variable overrides:

- **MemoryConfig**: Top-level configuration container
- **Provider-specific Configs**: Specialized configurations for LLMs, vector stores, etc.
- **Environment Variables**: MEM0_DIR for custom storage location
- **Telemetry Control**: MEM0_TELEMETRY to enable/disable analytics

### External Dependencies
- **Vector Databases**: Qdrant, Chroma, Pinecone, Weaviate, FAISS, and others
- **LLM Providers**: OpenAI, Anthropic, Azure, Gemini, Ollama, and others
- **Embedding Models**: Multiple providers including OpenAI, HuggingFace, VertexAI
- **Graph Databases**: Memgraph, Neptune, Kuzu
- **Analytics**: PostHog for telemetry

### Integration Points
- **API Endpoints**: REST API for external access
- **SDKs**: Python and JavaScript/TypeScript clients
- **Browser Extension**: Chrome extension for cross-platform memory
- **Framework Integrations**: Langchain, CrewAI, Langgraph support

### Component Relationship Diagram
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Memory] --> B[LLM Factory]
    A --> C[Embedder Factory]
    A --> D[Vector Store Factory]
    A --> E[Graph Store Factory]
    A --> F[SQLite Manager]
    A --> G[Telemetry]
    B --> H[LLM Providers]
    C --> I[Embedding Providers]
    D --> J[Vector Stores]
    E --> K[Graph Stores]
    F --> L[History Database]
    G --> M[PostHog Analytics]
    style A fill:#f9f,stroke:#333
```

## 4. Key Features

### Functionality Overview
Mem0 provides comprehensive memory management capabilities:

- **Memory Creation**: Extract facts from conversations and store them
- **Intelligent Updates**: Use LLMs to decide when to add, update, or delete memories
- **Procedural Memory**: Store sequences of actions for task completion
- **Memory Search**: Retrieve relevant memories based on queries
- **History Tracking**: Maintain complete history of memory changes
- **Multi-provider Support**: Flexible backend selection

### Implementation Highlights
The system implements a sophisticated memory management workflow:

1. **Fact Extraction**: Uses LLMs to identify key facts from conversation
2. **Memory Matching**: Searches existing memories for related information
3. **Update Decision**: Uses LLMs to determine appropriate action (add/update/delete)
4. **Storage**: Persists memories in vector stores with metadata
5. **History**: Records all changes in SQLite for audit and recovery

The implementation handles both synchronous and asynchronous operations, with thread and async task management for parallel processing.

### Feature Architecture Diagram
```mermaid
stateDiagram-v2
    [*] --> Idle
    Idle --> FactExtraction: add()
    FactExtraction --> MemorySearch: Extracted facts
    MemorySearch --> UpdateDecision: Existing memories
    UpdateDecision --> ApplyChanges: ADD/UPDATE/DELETE
    ApplyChanges --> VectorStore: Update vector DB
    ApplyChanges --> GraphStore: Update graph relationships
    ApplyChanges --> HistoryDB: Record change
    VectorStore --> Idle: Complete
    GraphStore --> Idle: Complete
    HistoryDB --> Idle: Complete
    
    state "LLM Operations" as llm_ops {
        FactExtraction
        UpdateDecision
    }
    
    state "Storage Systems" as storage {
        VectorStore
        GraphStore
        HistoryDB
    }
```

Sources:
- [README.md](c:\Users\hfeng1\mem0\README.md)
- [__init__.py](c:\Users\hfeng1\mem0\mem0\__init__.py)
- [main.py](c:\Users\hfeng1\mem0\mem0\memory\main.py)
- [base.py](c:\Users\hfeng1\mem0\mem0\memory\base.py)
- [storage.py](c:\Users\hfeng1\mem0\mem0\memory\storage.py)
- [setup.py](c:\Users\hfeng1\mem0\mem0\memory\setup.py)
- [telemetry.py](c:\Users\hfeng1\mem0\mem0\memory\telemetry.py)
- [base.py](c:\Users\hfeng1\mem0\mem0\configs\base.py)
- [enums.py](c:\Users\hfeng1\mem0\mem0\configs\enums.py)
- [prompts.py](c:\Users\hfeng1\mem0\mem0\configs\prompts.py)
- [factory.py](c:\Users\hfeng1\mem0\mem0\utils\factory.py)
</blog>
